raw_text:
Voters flock to blog awards site
 
 Voting is under way for the annual Bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year.
 
 Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed because of too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog, to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top US dictionary naming "blog" word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.
 
 Nikolai Nolan, who has run the Bloggies for the past five years, told the BBC News website he was not too surprised by the amount of voters who crowded the site. "The awards always get a lot of traffic; this was just my first year on a server with a bandwidth limit, so I had to guess how much I'd need," he said. There were many new finalists this year, he added, and a few that had won Bloggies before. Several entries reflected specific news events. "There are four nominations for the South-East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami Blog, which is a pretty timely one for 2005," said Mr Nolan.
 
 The big Bloggies battle will be for the ultimate prize of blog of the year. The nominated blogs are wide-ranging covering what is in the news to quirky sites of interest. Fighting it out for the coveted award are Gawker, This Fish Needs a Bicycle, Wonkette, Boing Boing, and Gothamist. In a sign that blogs are playing an increasingly key part in spreading news and current affairs, The South-East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami Blog is also nominated in the best overall category. GreenFairyDotcom, Londonist, Hicksdesign, PlasticBag and London Underground Tube Blog are the nominees in the best British or Irish weblog.
 
 Included in the other categories is best "meme". This is for the top "replicating idea that spread about weblogs". Nominations include Flickr, a web photo album which lets people upload, tag, share and publish their images to blogs. Podcasting has also made an appearance in the category. It is an increasingly popular idea that makes use of RSS (really simple syndication) and audio technology to let people easily make their own radio shows, and distribute them automatically onto portable devices.
 
 Many are done by those who already have text-based blogs, so they are almost like audio blogs. Three new categories have been added to the list this year, including best food, best entertainment, and best writing of a weblog. One of the categories that was scrapped though was best music blog. The winners of the fifth annual Bloggies are chosen by the public. Public voting closes on 3 February and the winners will be announced sometime between 13 and 15 March.
llama3.2:1b: Voters are flocking to the website for the annual Bloggies awards, with many nominees in 30 categories including regional blogs, best-kept-secret blogs, and online news sites.
The site was temporarily closed due to heavy traffic but is expected to reopen soon.
This year's nominations include popular blogs such as Gawker, Wonkette, and Boing Boing, which are vying for the award of blog of the year.
llama3.2:3b: Voters are currently casting ballots for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best weblogs of the year.
More than 12,000 new blogs were added daily in 2004, with traffic to the official site being so heavy that it was temporarily closed due to high visitors.
The awards have over 30 categories and nominees include notable sites such as Gawker, This Fish Needs a Bicycle, and Gothamist.
Voting closes on February 3 and winners will be announced between March 13-15.
gemma2:2b: The Bloggies awards recognize the best web blogs for 2004, with over six million blogs tracked by Technorati and new entries added daily.
This year's nominees are wide-ranging in topic and include notable blogs like Gawker, This Fish Needs a Bicycle, and Gothamist for blog of the year.
The South-East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami Blog is also nominated in the best overall category.
Several categories highlight emerging trends such as podcasting, meme culture, and online food.
Public voting closes on February 3rd, with winners announced between March 13th and 15th.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Blogies, an awards event for web blogs, attract voters from around the world.
Voting was announced last Sunday but traffic to the official site slowed down due to high numbers of visitors.
Weblogs have been nominated in multiple categories including tech sites such as Technorati and Twitter.
Many nominations for 2005's South-East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami Blog were made, with some having won earlier awards.
Nominations for best meme are included in the overall prize.
The Blogies battle aims to recognize blogs that have contributed most to news coverage.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Voters flooded the site for the annual Bloggies awards recognizing top web blogs, with traffic overwhelming a limited server bandwidth capacity.
Many new finalists were nominated in various categories, including "meme" for an idea spreading widely on blogs.
The blog of the year award drew significant interest from Gawker and other popular sites.
Blogger nominations included photo albums and audio blogging.
Best music blogs are no longer eligible due to their removal.
Public voting closes February 3 with winners announced March 13-15.
qwen2.5:3b: Voting is underway for the Bloggies, recognizing the best web blogs annually.

With nominations in over 30 categories, including regional and secret blogs, weblogs have seen significant growth with more than six million globally and a new blog created every five point eight seconds.
The website faced traffic issues due to high voter numbers.
Key battles include the ultimate blog of the year, as well as categories for specific topics like news events and memes (like Flickr and podcasting).
New categories added this year are best food, entertainment, and writing.
Winners will be chosen by public voting ending February 3rd, with announcements between March 13th-15th.

Technorati, an online search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: The Bloggies award ceremony was a high-stakes event with significant voter turnout, as the blog awards site was temporarily closed due to overwhelming traffic.

Nick Nolan highlighted his surprising attendance, noting server limitations forced him to guess traffic volume.

Many new finalists this year include entries that reflect specific news events, such as South-East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami Blog.
The biggest battle for the ultimate prize of blog of the year is between Gawker, This Fish Needs a Bicycle, Wonkette, Boing Boing, and Gothamist.

Nominations included many blogs covering news events, such as the South-East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami Blog, which was nominated in several categories, including best overall blog.
Other categories included best "meme", which recognized the spread of ideas among weblogs, and best audio podcasting.
Podcasting is an increasingly popular idea that allows people to make their own radio shows and distribute them automatically onto portable devices.
The winners of the Bloggies are chosen by the public through voting, which closes on February 3rd and the winners will be announced between 13 and 15th March.

chatgpt-4o-latest: Voting for the annual Bloggies awards, which recognize the best weblogs, is underway.
Heavy traffic temporarily shut down the official site after nominations were announced.
Blogs have grown significantly, with "blog" named the word of 2004 and millions being tracked by Technorati.
Organizer Nikolai Nolan noted the high voter turnout and highlighted new and returning finalists, including the South-East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami Blog.
The top prize, Blog of the Year, features nominees like Gawker, Boing Boing, and Wonkette.
Other categories include best British or Irish weblog, best "meme," and new additions like best food and best entertainment blog.
Public voting closes on 3 February, with winners announced in mid-March.
